abstract: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting.
snippet: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting.
lead_paragraph: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs against Iran, Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting. The European Union opened investigations into whether manufacturers of polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, in those areas receive excessive government aid and sell in the 27-nation bloc below cost, a practice known as dumping. PET users include plastic-bottle mold makers and bottlers including Coca-Cola. Under European Union practices, the commission can impose provisional antisubsidy duties for four months and provisional antidumping penalties for six months.
